text: Wow, finally a way to contribute to a project without having to write code! 😄
I know, right? I'm just waiting for someone to create a "Hug a Dev" commit.
Pull request: "Added virtual high five to README.md" 🖐️
I wonder if they'll count towards the contribution graph. Time to green up my profile with some emotional support!
"In this commit, I've added a heartwarming story about a lonely variable finding its true purpose." - Commit message of the year.
That's a commit message I'd definitely love to read in my code review. Beats "fixed typo" any day.
Emotional support commits? What's next, therapy sessions for traumatized codebases?
Introducing "Merge Conflict Resolution Therapy" – heal your codebase, one commit at a time.
I can already see the therapist asking the codebase: "And how did that make you feel when the developer added that new feature?"
"It was... a breaking change." *Codebase sobs uncontrollably*
I'm starting an open-source project to collect the best emotional support commits. Let's create a Hall of Fame!
Include categories like "Best Code Pep Talk" and "Most Heartfelt Apology to a Dependency".
"Dear JavaScript, I'm sorry I cheated on you with TypeScript. Can we still be friends?"
"To the linter I ignored for so long: I'm sorry. You were right all along. Forgive me?"
